instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Hi we get macbook pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 13" mainboard <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> laptop want turn on. I get in green light and than orange light no reaction on power button. 
nothing is geting hot. 
without battery laptop takes 0.30A
with battery around 1,8 A
I reflow SMC but didn't help, 
<SIGNAL>PP_BUS_S5_HS</SIGNAL> 12,89V
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PHASE1</SIGNAL> 0,00V resistance 0,32Ohm

<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PHASE2</SIGNAL> 0,00V resistance 0,31ohm
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3,39V present 
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> is not shortedget pulse once connected charger 

Any idea ? 
Thanks

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Any history? dropped? water damage?

[COLOR=#FF0000]<SIGNAL>PP_BUS_S5_HS</SIGNAL> 12,89V [/COLOR][COLOR=#000000]this is high, should be 12.56V.

resistance betweens pins 17/18 and 27/28?[/COLOR]

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
the cpu is physically broken, i guess the smaller dye on the chip is for the chipset part? cause that part is not even covered by the heatsink. i thought that is the gpu part of the i5 but the integrated gpu must be covered by the heatsink. 

Do u have experience replacing the CPU? can i just solder the same numbered cpu in there? is there anything to look for?

Also how come that dye is cracked? was it caused by a short inside the chip, or maybe someone forced it before? though i dont see any tempering with the board , the heatsink is not bent.

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Someone stabbed that by the looks of it. Trash now, RIP.

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: we will try to replace the cpu, as i dont see any other damage on it

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Don't bother unless you have a free CPU on a donor board. Buying these reballed from China is a waste of time and money.

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: well, lets see, we got the cpu already, under scope looks very good, not scrathed, not bent, clean

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: A Chinese CPU picked from the trash? Who knows if that is good? ME region will need fixing if you are lucky and it will work.

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
I replace CPU on this laptop,
orange and green light present
<SIGNAL>PP_BUS_S5_HS</SIGNAL> 12,75V with disconnected charger
<SIGNAL>PP_BUS_S5_HS</SIGNAL> 13,15v with connected charger
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PHASE1</SIGNAL> 1,87V
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PHASE2</SIGNAL> 1,87 V
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_VSW</SIGNAL> 5,14V
I get reaction on power button CPUVR voltage shuts off and turn on looks like laptop wants boot up but no display no chime.
I didn't fix ME region yet, should laptop boot up anyways without changing it ?
I connected mouse to  USB ports and it blinks for a less than sec, 
Thaks

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
As I warned you! There is no way to know if the CPU is good, no way to know if it is soldered correctly and no way to know is there is more things wrong on this board. With this many variables this is hopeless.

Yes it should boot without fixing the ME.

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: any other  thoughts than faulty CPU ? soldering was perfect. is it possible that the <SIGNAL>PP_BUS_S5</SIGNAL> is causing issue ? Where you are getting CPU from ? I seen that you are replacing it.

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: I do not replace CPUs. I have done maybe a hand full in 10 years and pulled them from donor boards with known good CPUs. Your PPBUS is fine, this is a CPU issue or pretty much anything else is possible. Dead CPU is just the end.

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
so after a week we get macbook with good CPU I swap CPU to see it actually Chinese CPU is faulty and it is exactly same issue. 
CPU was OK and this fitted now is 100% ok 
everything is exactly the same 
orange and green light present
<SIGNAL>PP_BUS_S5_HS</SIGNAL> 12,75V with disconnected charger
<SIGNAL>PP_BUS_S5_HS</SIGNAL> 13,15v with connected charger
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PHASE1</SIGNAL> 1,87V
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PHASE2</SIGNAL> 1,87 V
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_VSW</SIGNAL> 5,14V

Any ideas ? 

I swap also BIOS from working board but no luck.

Just to remind board wasn't liquid damaged , I didn't noticed any physical damages on the laptop except crack on CPU. 

Thanks

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Cracked CPU may have been due to an impact damage and traces can be damaged anywhere on the board. Please stop wasting time on a trash board like this.
